verses.text: Sing to the LORD a new song; sing to the LORD, all the earth!
verses.comment: The call for a 'new song' often signals fresh revelation or deliverance by God, anticipating the arrival of the Messiah. The invitation to all the earth prefigures the opening of salvation to all nations, not only Israel (see Isa. 42:10; cf. Rev. 5:9).

verses.text: Sing to the LORD, bless his name; proclaim his salvation day after day.
verses.comment: God's 'salvation' here is a present reality proclaimed continually, foreshadowing the continual proclamation of the Gospel. The call for daily worship has resonance with the practice of daily prayer and praise.

verses.text: Declare his glory among the nations, his marvelous works among all peoples.
verses.comment: This universal language anticipates the command of Christ to go and make disciples of all nations (Matt. 28:19). The spread of God's glory is central to salvation history.

verses.text: For the LORD is great and greatly to be praised; he is to be feared above all gods.
verses.comment: God's supremacy over all purported gods sets him apart. The 'fear' called for is reverence, not terror. It sets the stage for exclusive worship of the one true God, a key theme later emphasized in apostolic teaching.

verses.text: For all the gods of the peoples are idols, but the LORD made the heavens.
verses.comment: Contrasting lifeless idols with the Creator underscores the unique power and authority of the LORD. This verse strengthens the foundational doctrine of creation ex nihilo.

verses.text: Splendor and majesty are before him; strength and beauty fill his sanctuary.
verses.comment: 'Sanctuary' here can refer to both the physical temple and the heavenly reality. The language foreshadows the order and reverence in worship practices carried on through generations, and points subtly to the enduring importance of sacred space in worship.

verses.text: Ascribe to the LORD, O families of the nations, ascribe to the LORD glory and strength.
verses.comment: The call is not just to Israel, but to all peoples. This universal invitation anticipates the unity of all believers in worship, transcending ethnic boundaries.

verses.text: Ascribe to the LORD the glory due his name; bring an offering and come into his courts.
verses.comment: Bringing offerings and entering his courts indicates the importance of worship expressed in both spiritual praise and physical acts. Early Christian worship continued this pattern of offering prayers and gifts, entering into the presence of God in sacred assembly.

verses.text: Worship the LORD in holy splendor; tremble before him, all the earth.
verses.comment: The concept of 'holy splendor' indicative of reverence and awe in worship. Such worship is characterized by beauty and holiness, which influences both external and internal devotion.

verses.text: Say among the nations, 'The LORD reigns!' The world is firmly established, it will not be moved; he will judge the peoples with equity.
verses.comment: God's kingship is a core themeâ€”with eternal, firm establishment of his reign. His justice and judgment point forward to the promise of the Messiah's just reign (see Dan. 7:14), fulfilled in Christ as the righteous Judge.

verses.text: Let the heavens rejoice, and let the earth be glad; let the sea resound, and all that is in it.
verses.comment: Creation itself responds to God's kingship with joy, prefiguring the renewal of all creation under Christ's final victory (cf. Rom. 8:19-22).

verses.text: Let the fields be joyful, and everything in them; then all the trees of the forest will sing for joy
verses.comment: Nature's praise here is both poetic and prophetic, envisioning creation's participation in God's renewal and the joy of the righteous.

verses.text: before the LORD: for he comes, he comes to judge the earth. He will judge the world in righteousness, and the peoples in his faithfulness.
verses.comment: The expectation of the coming Judge prefigures the return of Christ, whose judgment is righteous and faithful. This verse echoes in the later teaching on the Last Judgment and the hope of ultimate justice.
